abstract.text: A scene graph node that serves as a placeholder for content to be loaded from a separate scene file.

inlineContent.text: When you tell a reference node to load its content, SceneKit loads the referenced scene file and makes children of the scene fileâ€™s root node become children of the reference node.

abstract.text: Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
Methods for running actions on nodes.
The common interface for attaching animations to nodes, geometries, materials, and other SceneKit objects.

and
classes for measuring location and size.
A three-dimensional shape (also called a model or mesh) that can be displayed in a scene, with attached materials that define its appearance.
A structural element of a scene graph, representing a position and transform in a 3D coordinate space, to which you can attach geometry, lights, cameras, or other displayable content.

property.
A scene graph node that serves as a placeholder for content to be loaded from a separate scene file.
Initializes a node whose content is to be loaded from the referenced URL.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the reference node has already loaded its content.
Loads content into the node from its referenced external scene file.
An option for whether to load the nodeâ€™s content automatically.
Creates a node whose content is to be loaded from the referenced URL.
The URL to a scene file from which to load content for the reference node.

Use nodes to define the structure of a scene.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.

A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.

A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
